WE your Majesty’s most dutiful and loyal subjects, the commons of Ireland in Parliament assembled, having a just sense of your royal care for the prosperity of all your subjects, and well knowing that the security of this your realm, and the continuance of the many blessings we enjoy under your mild and auspicious reign, depend on the support of your Majesty’s government, do most humbly beseech your Majesty that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and content of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That the several and respefiive additional rates, duties, and impolitions on all beer, ale, Itrong waters, wine, Ipi* rits, tobacco, and other goods and merchandizes, which by an act of Parliament'

CHAP. III.

An Act for allowing further Time to Perfom in Offices or Employments to qualify themselves purfnant to an Act, intituled, An Act to prevent the further Growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several persons well afFefted to his Majesty’s government and the church of Ireland, as by law eltablillied, may have through ignorance neglcfted, or been prevented by fleknefs or other unavoidable causes, from taking and subscribing the oaths, and making and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, An 08 to prevent tie further growth of popery, and by their * inadvertency may have incurred great penalties: be it enacted by the King's most cxcctlent Majesty by and with the advice and content of the lords fpititual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by-the authority of the fame, That all and every person or persons, who hare incurred any penalties and incapacities in the said act, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, mentioned, by neglcfting to qualify themselves according to the said act, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilrties, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred by reason of such omiflioa or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, or by authority derived from them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be queltioned or avoided by reason of such neglect or omtlfion: but all such acts shall he, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and eiTectual, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration, in manner as aforesaid; any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithftamling: Provided such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration in such manner and form, and in fitch place and places, as are dircfted and appointed by the said act to prevtnt the further growth of popery, on or before the first day of August, which shall be in the year of our Lord, one thousand seven hundred and sixty four.

CHAP. VII.

An Act for regulating the Proceedings ofgrand-juries in the preparing and forming of Presentments for the levying of Money.

WHEREAS presentments of grand-juries for raising publick money are often confirmed for want of due notice, that such presentments s were intended to be made and applied for: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and sixty four, no presentment, except presentments for bread for prisoners, or for the repairing or (trengthening gaols, and for bolts or (hackles, (locks, whipping-posts, ducking-stools, and pillories, and also excepting presentments for conveying of persons accused for any treason or felony to the county gaol pursuant to an act of Parliament made in this kingdom in the seventeenth year of his late Majesty King George the second, shall be confirmed, unless seven days notice (diltinguifliing therein the barony to be charged by such presentment, if to be a barony-charge) at lead thereof shall be given to the treasurer of the county previous to the affixes, in which application shall be made for such presentment, and which notice shall be given in writing and polled up by the said treasurer, or in case of his being disabled by sickness or absence, by such person as he shall appoint to perform the fame, on the door of the county court-house four days before the said assizes, and in the grand-jury room on the firil day of the said alfizes; of all which the said treasurer, or such person as he shall in case of sickness or absence as aforesaid appoint, shall make an affidavit before one of the judges of affize, before any presentment (except as before excepted) shall be confirmed.

If. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said treasurer of the county, or in case of his sickness or absence such person as he shall appoint as aforesaid, shall, and he is hereby required to, deliver a fair and true copy

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case such treasurer, or if he shall be sick, such person as he shall appoint, shall omit or neglect to do or perform, what is herein before required of him or either of them, then the said treasurer shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of ten pounds j and in case the clerk of the crown, or his deputy in case of his absence, upon receiving from the treasurer the said lift of all such notices as aforesaid, shall omit or neglect to do and perform, what is herein before required of him, or either of them, then that the said clerk of the crown shall for every such offence forfeit the like sum of ten pounds.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said forfeitures shall be recovered in a summary way by civil bill by any person or persons, who shall first sue for the fame at the next general assizes for the said county.

V. Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend to the county of the city of Dublin, or to the county of Dublin.

An Act for amending an Act,' intituled, An As to explain and amend an Act passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the First, intituled, An Act for the belter regulating the Parish Watches, and amending the Highways in this Kingdom:, and for preventing the Misapplication of Publick Money. '

WHEREAS provision has teen made by the said act for mating roads AptM from one market town to another in direct lines: and whereas the faid/ 1. 3 aft does not extend to the county of Dublin, as there are no assizes held for

I* Q. 2, IQ,

the said county: and whereas it is reasonable, that the said county should have/ %. the benefit of the said .prorifions as well as any other county: for which pur. pose be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and content of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That from and after the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and sixty four, it shall c , l0_

and may be lawful to and for the grand jury of the county of Dublin in Hil" f- *• lary and Trinity terms in every year to make such preferments for new roadsi as the grand juries of other counties arc impowered to do by the said act, subject nerertheless to such traverses as in the said act is mentioned.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid. That from and after the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and sixty four it' shall and may be lawful to and for the grand jury of any county at the assizes, and for the grand jury of the county of Dublin in the said terms, to present any old road or any part thereof to be flopped, where any new road has been or shall be made in lieu of such old road in pursuance of the said act or of this act.

III. Provided always. That if any person or, persons shall think him, her, or themselves aggrieved by flopping up such old road, it shall be lawful for such person to traverse such.presentment at the next assizes or at the second assizes after, or if in the county of Dublin in the.next term or the second term after, such preferment shall be made; and such traverse shall be tried by a jury; and in case such preferment shall not be traversed, or if traversed a verdict shall be found for the preferment, such preferment shall be confirmed.

WHEREAS it is found by experience, That the laws already in being have not been sufficient to prevent corrupt and illegal practices in the election of members to serve in Parliament: for remedy therefore of so great an evil, and to the end that all elections of members to Parliament, may hereafter

be freely and indifferently without charge .or expence, .be it enacted by the King’s moil excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That from and after the first day of June in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and sixty four, upon-every election of any member or members to serve for 5 Ac

the commons in Parliament every freeholder, citizen, freeman, burgess, or person, having or claiming to have a right to vote or be polled at such election, shall, before he is admitted to poll at the fame election, take the following oath, or, being of the people called quakers, shall make the solemn affirmation appointed for quakers, in case the fame shall be demanded by either of the candidates or any two of the electors; (that is to say)

I A. B. do swear (or being of the people called quakers, I A. B. do solemnly affirm) I have not received or bad by myself, or any person whatsoever in trust for me or for my tife and benefit, or for the life and belief t of any of my family or kindred, to my knowledge or belief, direBly or indireBly, any sum or funis of money, office, place, or employment, gift, or reward, or any promise or security for any money, office, employment, or gift, in order to give my vote at this elcuion; and that I have not before been polled at this clcBioti.

CHAP. XIX.

An Act for indemnifying all fitch Persons as have been or shall be aiding in the difperfng of Riots, and apprehending the Rioters.

WHEREAS of late many unlawful, riotous, and tumultuous assemblies have been in divers parts of this kingdom : and whereas it is the duty of justices of the peace, and of the sheriff, and under sheriff of the county, where any unlawful riot or tumultuous assembly shall be, taking with them, if need be, the power of the county, to arrest the offenders so as to bring them to justice: be it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent M III I ^ '°rC'S *P'lr'ltua' am' temPoral and commons in this present taking aditt- Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That on tonfmtto°* notice or knowledge of any such unlawful, riotous, and tumul-U"«uhi0t- tuous assembly every justice of the peace, sheriff, under sheriff, biles, cmlca- mayor, bailifl', and other head officer within the limits of their perfc^aml' respective jurisdicttions, taking with them the necessary fcifcoiion- alliftance, (and they are hereby authorized and impowered to

tiers; and in- ’ ' , J \ r

damnified for command all his Majesty’s subjects of age and ability, to be maimfng, or assisting to them therein) shall resort to the place, where such hurting; unlawful, riotous, and tumultuous assembly shall be, and there ' use their utmost endeavours to disperse the fame, and to apprehend and seize the offenders in order to their being proceeded against according to law; and that if the persons so unlawfully, riotouily, and tumultuously assembled, or any of them, shall happen to be killed, maimed, or hurt, in the difpcrfing, seizing, or apprehending, or the endeavouring to disperse, seize, and apprehend them, that then every such justice of the peace, sheriff, under sheriff, mayor, bailiff, head officer, or other peace officer, and all and Angular persons being aiding or assisting to them or any of them, shall be freed, discharged, and indemnified as well against the King’s Majesty, his heirs and successors, as against all and every other person and persons of, for, or concerning the killing, maiming, or hurting any such person or persons so unlawfully, riotouily, and tumultuously assembled, that shall happen to be so killed, maimed, or hurt as aforesaid; cuUmfagainst an(l n0 prosecution whatsoever shall be had or carried on

CHAP. XXII.

An Act for dfcharging all Arrears of Quit, Crown, and Comp of'lion Rents, which have been growing due for twenty Tears laf pajl, on the Terms, and in the Manner therein mentioned.

WHEREAS several lands, reilory, abbey, priory, monastery lands, tythes, fairs, tenements, and hereditaments, Chargeable with quit rents, crown rents, composition rents, as other chief rents payable to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, have been for many years passed returned by the collectors of his Majesty’s revenue, to whom such rents have been given in charge, as not to be found, and such rents have been constantly carried on, and returned in arrear; by means whereof such arrears do now amount to considerable sums of money, and will be great incumbrances on such lands, redory, abbey, priory, and monastery lands, tythes, fairs, tenements, and hereditaments, in case the fame should be hereafter discovered: and whereas it is apprehended from the great length of time, that such arrears have been carried on, and the changes of names that have happened in several of the said lands, redory, abbey prior)', monastery lands, tythes, fairs, tenements, and hereditaments, that the discovery of such lands, redory, abbey, priory, and mona-ftcry, lands, tythes, fairs, tenements, and hereditaments, and the recovery of such arrears, will become every day more diilicult and expensive, and that giving an encouragement to the present owners of such lands, redory, abbey, priory, monastery lands, tythes, fairs, tenements, and hereditaments, to discover the fame, so. as that the growing rents payable to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, may be hereafter pundually paid, will increase his Majesty’s revenue : be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual ■ and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That it shall and may be lawful to and for every person and persons, bodies politick and corporate, at any time before the twenty fifth day of March, which will be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy, to prefer his, her, or their petiti-

and for every horse, mare, gelding, mule, or afs, laden or unladen, and not drawing, the sum of one penny; and for every drove of oxen, cows, or neat cattle, the sum of twenty pence by the score, and so in proportion for any greater or lesser number; and for every drove of calves, hogs, Iheep, or lambs, the sum of ten pence by the score, and so in proportion for any greater or lesser number; and for every carriage, whereon shall be carried or born any millstone or millstones, two shillings and six pence; XII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may he lawful to and for the said surveyor and surveyors, and such person or persons as he or they, or the said trustees or any seven of them, shall appoint, to dig, raise, gather, and take any gravel, furze, sand, stones, or other materials out of the several grounds of any person or persons, not being a garden, orchard, or deer-park, yard, planted walk or walks, or avenue to a house, where any such materials are or may be found, and from time to time to carry away such and so much thereof, as the said surveyor or surveyors in their respective places shall adjudge neccifary for the repairing and amending the said highways or roads, paying such rate for such materials and for the damage to the owner or occupier of the ground, from which the fame shall be digged, raised, gathered, and carried away, as the trustees appointed or to be appointed to put this act in execution shall adjudge reasonable; and in case of any difference between such owner or occupier and the said trustees touching the value of the materials and damage aforesaid, the judges of assize or the justices of the peace at the next general assizes and general gaol delivery or quarter sessions to be holden in the county, where the said materials shall be digged, raised, or gathered, and from which the fame shall be carried away, may and shall adjudge, assess, and finally determine the fame; and in case any such owner or occupier of the grounds, where such materials may be had, or any other person, shall oppose or hinder the person or persons so as aforesaid authorized in searching for, raising, digging, or carrying away any gravel, furze, sand, stones, or other materials, every such person or persons so offending, being thereof convicted upon oath before one or more justice or justices of the peace for the said county where such offence shall be committed, shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of twenty shillings to be paid to the said trustees, and levied by distress and sale of the said offenders goods and chattels, in such manner as the penalties herein before mentioned are appointed to be levied..

An Act to prevent Frauds in the tanning of Hides, in the currying of Leather, and the making of Shoes and Boots.

A. D. 1763.

An Act for malting more convenient the Approaches to the City if Lublin by making a new Turnpike Road on the South Sole, the Weft Side, and the North Side of the said City, to commence at the Road leading from Lublin to Lonnybrook, and h terminate at Cavendish-street.

............... convenient to Ins Majesty’s subjects, ami rhe making a new road on tin

south fide, the well fide, and the north fide of the said city will in a great measure remove such inconvenience by opening a safe and easy communication between the great western, southern, and northern roads of this kingdom ami the different parts •of the city of Dublin, whereby great utility and benefit will arise, not only to the inhabitants of the city of Dublin, but to. the inhabitants of the several adjacent counties, and to the publick in general; CHAP. V.

An Act for ascertaining the Duty of Exc'fe payable upon the Importation of Brandy, Rum, and Geneva.

WHEREAS by an act made in the fourteenth and fifteenth years of the reign of King Charles the second, intitled, An act for the settling of the excise or new impofi upon his Majesty, his heirs and successors, according to the book of rates therein infcrled, there was laid upon every gallon of spirits made of-wine or cyder imported- the rate and duty of four pence; and upon every gallon of strong waters perfectly made, imported from beyond seas, the rate and duty of twelve pence: and whereas some doubts have been made and raised concerning certain liquors imported into this kingdom, called -brandy, ram, and geneva, whether the fame should pay the-rate and duty htid by the said act upon spirits made of wine or cyder imported, or the rate and duty laid thereby upon strong waters perfectly made imported from beyond' seas: -and whereas ever since the commencement of the said act, brandy upon the importation thereof into this' kingdom has been rated for the duty of excise as of the value of six shillings and eight pence the gallon, and rum and geneva ever since the first importation thereof into this" kingdom have been rated for the duty of excise as of the fame value with brandy, whereby the duties of excise received upon the importation of the. said commodities by virtue of and under the said act -have-been four pence the gallon, and no more: and whereas it is apprehended, that an increase of duty of eight-pence the gallon upon the said commodities over and above the duty, heretofore paid upon the‘importation thereof, would be a great temptation to-smugglers to run large quantities of the said commodities into this kingdom, and -would in many other respects be prejudicial to the trade thereof: therefore in order to remove -all such doubts for the future, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by-and with the advice-and-consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, that all brandy, rum, and geneva, which at any time heretofore hath been, or at any time hereafter shall lie, imported into this kingdom, shall be deemed and confulered at all times heretofore to have been, and at all times hereafter to bc/subject and liable to a duty of excise of four pence the gallon, and no more, under and by virtue of the said act.

An Act to prevent for the future tumultuous Risings of Persons within this Kingdom, and for other purposes therein mentioned.

H E R E A S it has frequently happened of late in different parts of this

kingdom, that several persons as well by night as in the day time have in a riotous, disorderly, and tumultuous manner assembled theinselves, and being • so assembled and met together have abused and injured many persons by aHhulting, wounding, or otherwise maltreating their persons, or by destroying or injuring their property, to the great detriment and disturbance of several of his Majesty’s loyal and faithful subjects, and have forceably imposed. sundry oaths contrary to law, and which, if not timely prevented, may become dangerous to the general peace of this kingdom, and his Majesty’s government therein: for preventing thereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That from and after the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and sixty six if any persons to the number of five or more (lull meet, and go by night, and act'ault, injure, or otherwise maltreat any psrfon or persons by wounding, beating, tying, or by any other act of cruelty, whereby the life or limb of the person assaulted may be in danger, or fell wilfully

or maliciottlly destroy or injure his, her, or their property, by killing, maiming, or worrying their cattle, or by destroying or spoiling their house or houses, barns, mills, or mildams, hay, corn, or grain, or potatoes, whether the fame be growing, handing, or lying in the field or haggard, or maliciously digging up ground, that all and every person or persons so offending, and being thereof found guilty, lliall fuller death as in cases of felony without benefit of clergy.

Vlll. Provided always, that if the carriage of such goods and commodities from one place to another shall be prevented from being fully performed within the time limited in such permit by any unforeseen or unavoidable accident, then, on notice being immediately given by the owner or carrier of such goods or commodities to any officer of the revenue, and a rest or flay being made of such goods or commodities at or near the place, where such accident shall happen, the officer of the revenue, to whom such notice shall be given as aforesaid, shall without any delay repair to the place, where such goods and commodities shall then he; and if such officer shall find-upon view or enquiry, such goods and commodities were Hopped or delayed in their carriage by any such accident as. before mentioned, then and in such case such officer shall thereupon by indorsement on such permit enlarge the time for the carriage of the said goods to the place of their first destination; and if any officer of the revenue shall wilfully *or negligently omit or refuse to do his duty herein according to the directions aforesaid, such officer shall, on proof being made thereof to the satisfaction of the chief commissioners of his Majesty’s revenue, or any three or more of them, forfeit" and lose the sum of ten pounds.

XXV. And whereas it has frequently happened, that collectors of his Majesty’s revenue and their clerks have respectively run in arrear to his Majesty, and have thereupon absconded and withdrawn themselves so as not to be discovered, and have carried with them or secreted the several books of account, relating to his Majesty’s revenue under their collection and care, with intent to prevent the chief commissioners of his Majesty’s revenue, or the officers employed under them to examine their several accounts, entries, and disbursements in order to ascertain the balance remaining due to his Majesty after all just allowances: for remedy of which evil be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the said twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and sixty six if any collector, or clerk of any collector, or other person or persons whatsoever, shall wilfully destroy, or cause to be destroyed, or shall with design to defraud his Majesty, his heirs or successors, wilfully obliterate or deface, or cause to be obliterated or defaced, any of the books of account appertaining to his Majesty’s revenue, or be-longing to any custom house or excise office within this kingdom, then and in that case every such collector, clerk of any collector, or other person or persons whatsoever, on being legally convicted thereof, shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and shall suffer the pains and,.penalties of death without benefit of clergy, or of the statute.

An Act for the further Encouragement of Tillage in this Kingdom.

’IfTTHEREAS the laws heretofore made for the encouragement of tillage in ^ * * this kingdom have not had the desired efleft: be it enacted by the King’s moil excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and •temporal and' commons in this.present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That from and after the -first day of March in the year one thousand seven hundred and sixty seven, when wheat shall not exceed the price of six shillings per hundred weight, barley the price of three shillings and nine pence per hundred weight, and oats the price of three shillings per hundred weight, any merchant or other person who shall put on ship board in firitish or Irish shipping, the mailer and two thirds of the mariners at lead being his Majesty’s subjects, any of the said forts of corn in any port within this kingdom, when the rates shall not be higher than as before mentioned, with intent to export the fame beyond the seas, except to the Isle of Man, shall, after entering into such bond and performing the several other requisites directed by an act of Parliament made in this kingdom in the twenty ninth year of the reign of his late Majesty King-George the feeond, have and receive from the collector or officer of such port respectively, instead of the allowances to be made by virtue of the said act, the rates, allowances, or premiums following, and no more, that is lo say, for every hundred weight of wheat eight pence j for every hundred weight of barley five pence; for every hundred weight of oats five pence; which said several sum or Aims of money respectively such collector or officer is hereby authorized and required to pay to such exporter upon demand without requiring ox taking any cuilora, fee, or reward for such com so laden to be exported any law, statute, or usage to the contrary notwithfhuiding.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the firil day of March in the year one thousand seven hundred and sixty seven all preferments of the rates or prices of corn (Ini! be by the (lone weight.

HI. VII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforefaiil, That the governors and governeffes of each respective infirmary (five of whom shall be a quorum) shall have four general quarterly meetings in every year at such respective infirmary Or hospital; and.shall at any general meeting have power to tied or remove a physician, or surgeon, and servants, and to order and regulate the whole ceconomy and expences of such respective infirmaries or hospitals, and shall have power to appoint (landing committees to insped the management thereof in the intervals between the general meetings j and in case of a vacancy of a physician or surgeon by death or otherwise to summon by adver-tifement in two of the Dublin news papers general boards on those particular occaftons for the purpose of supplying every such vacancy; at which general boards five shall he a quorum.

VIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the governors and governefles of each respective infirmary or hospital at their first general meeting, and from time to time thereafter at any general board, as occasion shall require, shall and are hereby impowered to appoint a treasurer of the said infirmary or hospital; who shall receive all annual fubl'crip-tions and donations for the benefit of the said infirmary ot hospital, and shall act without fee or reward, and he accountable to the governors and governefles at their four general quarterly meetings: and that the said governors and governefles shall anil may sue and recover from such treasurer all sums by hi in received for the benefit of such infirmary or hospital.

IX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no patient shall be admitted into any of the said infirmaries but upon a written recommendation from one of the governors or governefles of the said infirmary or hospital, certifying that such a person is a proper object of the said charity, except in cases of sudden accidents, which may require immediate relief; in which cases it shall be diferetionary in the physician or surgeon of the said infirmary or hospital to receive or reject such patient; and in case it shall happen, that more patients shall be so recommended, than any of the said infirmaries or hospitals shall be capable of receiving, then the physician or surgeon shall admit them according to the priority of their several recommendations; and the certificates shall be carefully preserved by the respective physicians and surgeons as vouchers, that the patients were admitted in the manner aforesaid.

CHAP. XXI.

An Act for the'belter regulating of Trials in Cafes of High Treason under the Statute of the twenty fifth of Edward the third.

WHEREAS it is highly reasonable and agreeable to the nature of our excellent confutation, that persons prosecuted for high treason under the statute of the twenty fifth of Edward the third should be allowed all proper means for defence of their innocence: in order thereto^ and for the better regulating of the trials of all such persons, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords l'piritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, That from and after the first day of August in this year one thousand seven hundred and sixty six all and every person and persons, who shall be acculed and indicted for high treason under the said statute, shall have a true copy of the whole indictment delivered to them, or any of them, upon requell, five days at least before he or they shall be tried for the lame j whereby to enable them, or any of them re-fpcftively, to advise with council thereon to plead and make their defence, his or their attorney or attorneys, agent or agents, requiring the fame, and paying the officer for such copy two /hillings and six pence, and no more.

11. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every such person so accused and indidled, arraigned or tried, for any such offence as aforesaid, shall be received and admitted to make his and their full defence by council learned in the law ; and the court, before whom such person or persons-shall be tried, or any judge thereof, shall and is hereby authorized and required immediately upon his or their requclt to assign to such person or persons such and so many council, not exceeding two in number (as lie or they shall desire) to plead for and aflill such person or persons in making their defence, any law or usage to the contrary notwithstanding.

And whereas by the before mentioned ail made in the first year of the reign of his present Majesty, it was enacted, That it should be lawful for the mayor, sheriffs, and commonalty of the city of Cork, to build a Hone bridge over a branch of the river Lee, running through the said city, from the quay of-polite to the street called Princes-street on Dunfcombs Marsh in the said city, to the northern or opposite part of the island called Lavits liland, and to build one other bridge of two done arches, and a lifting or portcullis bridge over the southern channel of the said river, to the .Red Abby Marsh: and whereas it hath been found that it would be more useful to the inhabitants of the said city, and to the trade thereof, that a draw bridge or portcullis bridge should be made in the place, where by the said act the Hone bridge was appointed to be built, namely, from the quay opposite to the street called Princes, to the opposite part of the said Lavits Island : be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it may and shall be lawful for the mayor, sheriffs, and commonalty of the said city of Cork, to take down the stone bridge, which hath been erected over the said branch of the river Lee, which runs between the said island and Dunfcomb’s Marsh, and in the place and Head thereof, to build and erect a turn or draw bridge, or portcullis bridge ; and to build, erect, or finilli a stone bridge of three arches over the southern channel of the said river, from the said island to the said Red Abby Marsh, in the place where the bridge of two stone arches and a portcullis bridge was by the said act appointed to be built.

County of Roscommon.

An At7for making a ’Turnpike Road leading from the Town of Mo-nejlerevan in the County of Kildare, to the Town of Portarling-lon, and from thence to the Towns of Mo untmellick andRofcnalUs in the Queen's County, and from thence to the Town of Birr in the King's County, and from, thence to Labincb near the River Shannon in the County of Tipperary.

WHEREAS the highways or roads leading from the city of Dublin through the towns of Moneftereven in the county of Kildare, to the towns of Port’arlington, Mountmellick, and Rofenallis in the Queen’s county, and from thence to the town of Birr in the King’s county, and from thence to Lahiuch near the river Shannon in the county of Tipperary, by reason of, the many windings and turnings thereof, and of the steep hills and hollow ways through which the said road from Monefterevan to Lahinch pafles, and the deepness of the foil, and the great scarcity and want of gravel convenient or- contiguous thereto, are become so ruinous and bad, that in the winter season many parts thereof are impassable for waggons, carts, cars, and carriages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept in good repair : wherefore, and to the intent that the said highways or roads may with convenient speed be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel through the fame with safety ; be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament afieillblcil, Vol. IX. 5 S and

CHAP. XXVJI.

An Act for the more effeBnal keeping in Repair the Road IcaJ-.ing from the Bridge of Dundalk in the County of Lo-wtb through the hinds of Fork'll to the Bridge of Mowhan, and from thence to the Newry Turnpike Road near the Eight Mile Stout in the County of Armagh.

WHEREAS the highway or road leading from the bridge of Dundalk in the county of Lowth through the lands of Forkij to the new bridge of Mowhan, and from thence to ■the Newry turnpike road near the eight mile stone in the county of Armagh, being found of general utility and advantage to travellers going through and from the northern parts of this kingdom, and of late very greatly frequented, and by reason of the great expence, which hath already attended the laying out and •new making the greater part of the said road, the lame cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the Jaws and statutes of this .realm be effectually amended and kept in good and suficient repair,: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highway and ■road be 'hereafter kept in good and suficient repair, be it enacted by the King’s moll; excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, Trustcei That it shall and may be lawful to and for his grace - the lord pri-mate, the right honourable James earl of Clanbraflil, the right honourable James -earl of Charlemont, Sir Archibald Achefon,

VI. And whereas great frauds and abuses have been committed by the clandestine importation of tea from parts beyond the seas without paying any duties for such tea: for remedy whereof, and for the greater discouragement of the pernicious and illegal practice of unlawfully importing and clandestinely running and landing of tea, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and sixty seven until the twen- ' ty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and sixty nine inclusive there shall be paid to your Majesty, your 6d. pcrii>. heirs and successois, the sum of six pence, and no more, for every pound of green tea, and the sum of four pence, and no ?"<) <>iWri«,

CHAP. III.

An Act for limiting the Duration of Parliaihenls.

THAT whereas a limitation of the dutation of Parliaments may tend to strengthen the harmony and good agreement subsisting between his Majesty and his people of Ireland, and may be productive of other good effects to his Majesty’s subjects there: we, your Majesty’s most dutiful and loyal subjects, the commons of Ireland in Parliament assembled, do most humbly beseech your Majesty, That it may be declared and enacted in this present Parliament, and be it declared and enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority, of the fame, That from henceforth no Parliament, which shall at any time hereafter be called, assembled, or held, shall have any longer continuance than for eight years, to be accounted,frohi the day on which by the writs of summons the said Parliament shall be appointed to meet.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforefaiil, That this present Parliament shall cease and determine on the twenty fourth day of June, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and sixty eight, unless his Majesty shall think fit sooner to diftoive the fame.

CHAP. XIII.

An Act for altering, amending, explaining, anil rendering more effectual an Act, made in the ninth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, An Act for repairing the Road leading from the Bridge, commonly called Banbridge, over the Ban Water in the County of Down to Rand alsown in the County of Antrim.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the ninth year of the reign of his late Majesty King George the second, intitled, An act for repairing the road leading from the bridge, commonly called Banbridge, over the Ban Water in the county of Down lo Rand alsown in the county of Antrim, several tolls and duties were granted and made payable for repairing the said road, and for the other purposes in the said act mentioned; which said act was to commence from and after the second Tuesday in the month of May in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty six, and from thence to continue in force for the .term of forty one years: and whereas the trustees appointed to put the said act into execution having borrowed several films of money on the credit thereof, and having applied the fame, together with the tolls collected by virtue of the said last in part receited act, in amending the said road; but the tolls proving in-fullicient to repair the said road, or to pay the sums so borrowed, and being but barely sufficient to pay the interest of the sums so borrowed, and the said road by reason of the great scarcity of materials to repair and amend the fame, and the length and extent thereof from the said bridge, commonly called Banbridge, Voi, IX. 6 U to

CHAP. XVIII.

An Act for the Relief if the Creditors of Theophilus Dcjbr 'say of the City of Dublin, esquire.

WHEREAS the said Theophilus Delbrifay did for many years follow the business of an agent to several regiments of horse, dragoons, and foot on the establishment in this kingdom, and having contrafted many debts, on the twenty ninth day of September one thousand seven hundred and sixty seven failed in his credit: and whereas the said Theophilus Dclbrifay is far advanced in years, and not likely to live long, so that his effects may be embezzled, or a partial distribution made thereof after his death, wherefore for the more effectual relief of the creditors of the said Theophilus Delbrifay, and providing as far as may be for the payment of the debts due to them, and in order thereto that the estates real, freehold, and personal of the said Theophilus Delbrifay may be applied in or towards satisfac-tion of their debts in such manner, as herein after is directed, at the humble petition of your Majesty’s dutiful subjects the right reverend Richard lord bishop of Waterford, the right honourable Nathaniel Clements, his excellency fir Joi’eph York knight of the bath, sir William Boothby baronet, major general John Severene, lieutenant general Peregrine Lafcclles, Thomas Bligh> and David Latouche esquires, in behalf of themselves and several other creditors of the said Theophilus Delbrifay, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this preferit Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame,

CHAP. XIX.

An Act for Ucenfmg Howlers and Pedlars, and for Encouragement of Etiglish Prokfant Schools.

WHEREAS the continuing the encouragement formerly given to English pro-

testant schools will be of great benefit to this kingdom; ami it is reason- I?'0' able, that some publick fund should be applied and set apart for that purpose : therefore be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice V0L1 IX. 7 E and

570 The seventh Year of George III.

£ and content of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this presentParlia-

CHAP. XXV.

An Act for the Relief of Debtors with respect to the Imprisonment of their Persons.

HEREAS many persons suffer by the oppression of inferior officers in nrpaUhyu

the executionof process for debt, and the cxadtions of gaolers to whom such debtors are committed: for remedy whereof it may be reasonable not only to enforce the execution of the laws now in being against such oppressions and cxadtions, but Jikewife to make some further .provisions for the ease and relief of debtors, who shall be willing to satisfy their creditors to the utmost of their power: be it therefore enacted by the KingYmofl excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament act'embled, and by the authority of the fame, That no ffieriff, under ffieriff, bailiff, serjeant at mace, or other officer or minified whatsoeverffiall at any time or times hereafter convey or carry, or cause to be conveyed or carried, any person or persons by him or them arrested, or being in his or their custody by virtue or colour of any writ, process, or warrant, to .any tavern, ale-house, or other publick victualling or drinking house, or to the private house of any such officer or minister, or of any tenant or relation of his, without, the free and voluntary consent of the person or persons so arrested or in custody, nor charge any such person or persons with any sum of money for any wine, beer, ale, victuals, tobacco, or any other liquor or things whatsoever, save what lie, she, or they-dhall call for of his, her, or their own free accord; nor shall cause or procure him, her, or. them to call or pay for any such liquor or things, except what he, she, or they shall particularly and freely ask for; nor shall demand, take, or receive, or cause to be demanded, taken or received dircdtly or indirectly any other or greater sum or sums of money, than is or shall be by law allowed to be taken or demanded for such arrest, taking, detainiqg, or waiting, till, the person or persons so arrested or in custody shall have given an appearance or bail as the case shall require, or agreed with the person or persons, at whose suit or prosecution he, (be, or they shall be taken or arrested, or until lie, file, or they shall be sent to the proper gaol belonging to the .county, city, town or place, where such arrest or taking shall be ; An Act for applying the Sum of Six Thousand Pounds, granted by Parliament to the Corporation for promoting and carrying on an inland Navigation in this Kingdom, to be by them applied in carrying on a Navigation from the City of Limerick to the deep navigable Water above the Town of Killaloe, and for encouraging other Persons to subscribe for carrying on and compleating the said Work at their own Expence.

WH E RE A S by an act passed this fession, entitled, an Act for granting and continuing to his Majesty an additional duty on beer, ale, strong waters, wine, tobacco, bides, and other goods and merchandizes therein mentioned, and for prohibiting the importation of all gold and silver lace, (except of the manufacture of Great Britain,) the sum of six thousand pounds was granted to the corporation for promoting and carrying on an inland navigation in this kingdom, to be by them applied towards carrying on the navigation of the river Shannon from the city of Limerick to the deep navigable water above the town of Killaloe, as soon as the sum of ten thousand pounds shall be subscribed for compleating the said work, and twenty pounds per cent, thereof shall be paid into such person or persons, as shall for that purpose be appointed by the said corporation.: and whereas it is reasonable and just, that the persons, who shall advance their money in pursuance of the said act, Ihould be entrusted with the conduct of the said works, and Ihould also have some compensation for their expence and trouble.: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the fame, that the said corporation shall on or before the first day of June next open a subseription for carrying on and compleating the said navigation; and that the fame shall be kept open, until the sum of ten thousand pounds shall be subscribed for the purpose aforesaid.

And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case of refusal to pay the said several rates and duties it shall and may be lawful to and for the said company and their servants either to diilrain such boats, barges, or other vessels, or the goods therein, for the fame, and to dispose thereof as is ufiial in cases of distress for non payment of rent, or to sue for and recover the fame by civil bill; and in case any dispute shall arise concerning the film to be paid for any such rate, the fame shall be adjusted by any justice of the peace of the county or city of Limerick, with liberty of appeal to either party from such determination to the next going judges of assize for the county of Limerick, whose determination therein shall be final.

XXVIII. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case any person or persons shall wilfully break down or damage any of the works, which are already made or which shall be made for the use of the said navigation, all and every person and persons so offending, and being thereof convicted upon an information or indictment, shall forfeit to the said company treble the sum necessary to be laid out in repairing such damage ; which sum shall be ascertained by the jury, who shall try such offence; and the judge, before whom such offence shall be tried, shall commit such offender or offenders to the common gaol, till he or they shall pay to the said company the sum or funis so ascertained; and such offence may be layed or tried either in the county or in the county of the city of Limerick.

XXIX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any suit shall be commenced or prosecuted against any person or persons for any thing, which shall be done in pursuance of this act, such person or persons may plead the general issue, and give the special matter in evidence; and this act shall be deemed and taken to be a publick act.
